page.title: 03Ecology of Eccleshall
page.content: Mainly farmland, the area is threaded with country roads amd public foot- paths providing many pleasant walks. Previous use of sprays has meant the loss of rare wildflowers, but present thoughtful council maintenance of road side verges has re-established many commoner species. Fox coverts, spin- neys and stands of trees on field slopes make attractive landmarks; and hadgerow trees of oak and ash are common and increasing under local policy. Weather conditions and temp- eratures are rarely extreme. The river Sow, in places edged with alder and willow, flows through{Copmere,}a 45 acre ice-age lake fringed by reeds and woodland. There are other private pools including Castlemere which forms part of a Nature Reserve leased to the {Staffordshire Conservation Trust.
